subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I can't assign ah/awe/ox, and the helpful chart made it worse.  Help?
msgSnippet: Read Alphabet as Shaw s alphabet are better used as a private shorthand.  For correspondence, you need to ask the other person if he has difficulty with any
messageBody:
Read Alphabet as Shaw's alphabet are better used as a private shorthand.  For correspondence, you need to ask the other person if he has difficulty with any of your written words.  The vowel sounds in particular can be confusing.  I myself prefer to use the example in Androcles and the Lion.  It isn't too far off from American English and since many people used it to learn the Shaw's alphabet, I think it is most appropriate. 
 
Understanding these points, there is no need to concern yourself about whether a vowel is pronounced one way or another.  There is a Read alphabet fellow who has simplified vowel sounds but the script is a bit slower than Read's alphabet.
 
Have a nice day,
 
Sid


--- On Thu, 2/4/10, fctarbox3 <fctarbox3@...> wrote:

From: fctarbox3 <fctarbox3@...>
Subject: [Read_Alphabet] Re: I can't assign ah/awe/ox, and the helpful chart made it worse. Help?
To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
Date: Thursday, February 4, 2010, 1:12 PM

 

Double post! Sorry, right after I hit post, I remembered seeing this video so many years ago.

http://www.youtube. com/watch? v=3UgpfSp2t6k

Conveniently her name is Walker... The Californian Ms. Walker says her name with the thaw vowel. The Brooklyn Ms. Walker says her name with the thought vowel. Five is pretty close, too, but a little exaggerated. Born sounds somewhat like it, too. Those three are all in the right neighborhood.
